title: In pursuit of Love Chapter 8 : On this Valentine's Day I confessed.
author: Benjamin G Nechicattu
description: to my crush, to my one-sided love, and most of all, to myself.
content:
I didn't do it expecting a miracle. I didn't imagine background music or a perfect reply. I just reached a point where carrying the words inside me felt heavier than the risk of saying them out loud. So I chose honesty over silence.

For a long time, my feelings lived quietly, like an unplayed song. I smiled, listened, pretended everything was casual while my heart wrote entire letters she would never see. One-sided love teaches you to become an actor in your own life â€” careful, controlled, always afraid to reveal too much. But emotions are not meant to be hostages.

Confessing wasn't about making her love me back. It was about refusing to keep lying to myself.

Emotional freedom, I learned, doesn't begin when someone says "me too." It begins the moment you stop being ashamed of what you feel. I loved â€” softly, genuinely, without expectation â€” and that is not something to hide. The world teaches us that unreturned love is embarrassing. But what is embarrassing about having a heart that knows how to care?

When I finally spoke, my voice wasn't heroic. It was nervous, imperfect, human. Yet in that trembling moment I felt lighter than I had in months. Whether she sees me differently or not, I no longer have to meet her while pretending my heart is silent.

One-sided love is often painted as a tragedy. But maybe it is also a proof â€” proof that we are capable of deep feeling without guarantees, that we can choose honesty even when the ending is unknown. That takes courage most people never practice.

This Valentine's Day didn't give me a love story.

It gave me something rarer â€” the freedom to be real.

I don't know what changes after this. Maybe nothing. Maybe everything. But at least my heart is no longer hiding behind polite smiles and unsent messages. I showed up as I am, and that is a kind of victory no rejection can take away.

So to anyone holding a secret love â€” you are not foolish. You are not "too much." You are simply someone who felt deeply in a world that fears depth. And if you ever choose to say it out loud, know this: the courage itself is already a beautiful ending.
